conclusion: The process C→D is an isothermal process, meaning the temperature T remains constant.
In an isothermal process for an ideal gas, the product of pressure p and volume V is constant: pV = constant.
The pressure p exerted by an ideal gas can be related to the number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time.
The relationship is given by the kinetic theory of gases: p = (1/3) n m v^2.
For a given temperature T, the average kinetic energy of the molecules is constant: (1/2) m v^2 = (3/2) k_B T.
Substituting into the pressure equation: p = n k_B T.
Pressure p is directly proportional to the number density n when temperature T is constant.

premise: n = pV/RT and T is constant
conclusion: Number density n is directly proportional to the product pV.

premise: pV is constant in an isothermal process

conclusion: Number density n remains constant throughout the isothermal process C→D.

premise: n is constant and v is determined by constant T
conclusion: The number of molecular collisions per unit area per unit time remains constant.
